results.firPara: The thing about cricket, someone said at the Wisden dinner the other night, is that it has this image of being a staid and stuffy old game that never changes. But it isn't like that all. It's in a state of permanent revolution. It's almost Maoist.

images.caption: Supporters watch from a bench on the opening day of the county cricket season at Wantage Road, where Northamptonshire played Glamorgan.
Ross Thorley gives the Northamptonshire boardroom a final clean before the start of the season.
Children play their own game around the edge of the County Ground.

results.secPara: The game is, to say the very least, bewildering, even for people who once kidded themselves that they understood it. The 2017 county cricket season began on Friday and will finish on 28 September. In the old days the counties did not play at all when there was an R in the month. This suggests that part of cricket's radicalism is a fervent belief in global warming.
results.webTitle: T20 plan is another step on cricket’s sleepwalk to a big-city business model | Matthew Engel

results.firPara: It has been a strange start to the cricket season. The established pattern is that the summer game – misnamed since so much of the action takes place in spring and autumn – creeps into action as dozily as a hedgehog coming out of hibernation. But this year cricket somehow seems more prominent.

images.caption: The Lancashire and England opening batsman Haseeb Hameed has raised very high expectations.

results.secPara: Usually there is just the shuffling of the shelf to make room for the latest Wisden, whose 154th edition was launched at Lord's on Wednesday. Another yellow-bound beauty, another notch in the passage of time. For those revelling in symmetry and order, which accounts for so many cricket nuts, the latest Wisden just has to be perused and then plonked alongside the rest of them.
results.webTitle: County cricket returns with a curious buzz around the English game | Vic Marks

results.firPara: Perhaps it should not be surprising it takes someone of Billy Vunipola's size to tackle the elephant in the room. Everyone says  ‘I'm not thinking about the Lions' – they're all lying, he says. It's all the media training, everyone is scared of saying  ‘I'm scared of not going.'
results.secPara: Vunipola is in candid mood. Here is an England international admitting defeat in Dublin may be a good thing, a member of the all-conquering Saracens side shining a light on their secrets of success and a would-be Lion revealing he is kept awake at night for fear of being overlooked by Warren Gatland.
results.webTitle: Saracens’ Billy Vunipola: ‘You build relationships by being vulnerable’

results.firPara: Wonder horse Winx has won an extraordinary 17 races in a row, after taking out the $4m Queen Elizabeth Stakes at Randwick in Sydney.
results.secPara: Hugh Bowman rode the mare to victory from an ideal barrier placing, coming from the outside to overtake Hartnell, who was followed by Sense of Occassion.
results.webTitle: Winx records 17th-straight win at Queen Elizabeth Stakes

results.firPara: Sergio García, Thomas Pieters and Rickie Fowler grabbed a share of Charley Hoffman's lead on another tough day at Augusta

images.caption: Rickie Fowler plays a shot from a bunker on the second.
Phil Mickelson remains in contention, here making a birdie on the seventh,
Rory McIlroy walks off the 18th at the end of a frustrating second round.
Lee Westwood reacts after a missed putt.

results.secPara: Sergio García, Thomas Pieters and Rickie Fowler grabbed a share of Charley Hoffman's lead on another tough day at Augusta
results.webTitle: The Masters 2017: second round – as it happened

results.firPara: Odds of 50-1 look far too big for the 2014 Cheltenham Gold Cup winner and allow for a good return each-way, even if he finds something finishing more strongly
results.secPara: Contrary to what regular readers may imagine, I do not generally like to provoke laughter with my big-race selections but I am steeling myself against the inevitable response because Lord Windermere (5.15) looks like the Grand National winner to me. A smile is the most restrained reaction one can expect from racing fans in response to this suggestion because the general view is that this horse has, in the parlance, ‘gone at the game'.
results.webTitle: Talking Horses: Lord Windermere tipped to shine in our Grand National preview

results.firPara: The American clung on to a share of the lead in Augusta as he finished with a three-over-par 75 on the second day, level with Sergio García
results.secPara: It took 36 hours and 23 holes but sometime around midday on Friday Charley Hoffman, a portly 40-year-old ranked No52 in the world, finally realised he was playing in the Masters. For the last day-and-a-half, Hoffman seemed to have fooled himself into thinking he was playing in some small town Sunday fundraiser, the Pro-Am at Podunk Country Club.
results.webTitle: Laid-back Charley Hoffman still running with the pack at the Masters

results.firPara: There were times recently when, despite a dominant car and two Formula One world championships, it appeared Lewis Hamilton was not taking much pleasure in climbing behind the wheel. The battle with his former friend Nico Rosberg was marked by ill-temper and the dynamic between him and his team was strained. The lack of competition from the rest of the grid had made the title fight a personal and internal battle at Mercedes for three years. Not anymore. Ferrari's resurgence has re-energised the fight, united the team and has Hamilton raring to go again.
results.secPara: The enthusiasm for a proper inter-team battle is more than shared by Hamilton. In China, having started the season solidly beaten into second place by Ferrari's Sebastian Vettel in Australia, the overwhelming impression from the three-times world champion was one of pleasure at the challenge presented by defeat.
results.webTitle: Ferrari’s F1 resurgence rekindles Lewis Hamilton’s love of high-speed duels

results.firPara: • Wolves record first win of the season with 25-14 victory• Salford Red Devils record crushing 54-18 win at Hull FC

images.caption: Warrington Wolves celebrate after breaking their seasonal duck against Leeds Rhinos.

results.secPara: Leeds Rhinos, who had started the day in second place behind Castleford Tigers, received a shock at the hands of Warrington Wolves. The home team had only mustered a single point from their opening seven games but won 25-14 at Halliwell Jones Stadium, their first victory of what had been a miserable campaign.
results.webTitle: Super League round-up: Warrington Wolves shock Leeds Rhinos

results.firPara: If the weight of experience lurking with intent did not pose such a threat, this Masters could be characterised as a weekend chase for major number one.

images.caption: Sergio García of Spain walks to the 18th green during the second round of the 2017 Masters

results.secPara: Charley Hoffman, Sergio García, Thomas Pieters and Rickie Fowler head the event at half way on four under par. At differing ages, positions in world ranking and career victory levels, their combined major haul? Zero. Hoffman is the surprise package, Pieters the surly young pretender, García the routine bridesmaid and Fowler the form horse. Cases can be made for each of them but, crucially, for another 25 competitors, too.
results.webTitle: Sergio García shines at Masters to raise hopes of end to major drought
